questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
Which one of the following is correct order of given isotopes?

I. T2 > D2 > P2 (order of boiling point)

II. T2 > D2 > P2 (order of bond energy)

III. T2 = D2 = P2 (order of bond length)

IV. T2 < D2 < P2 (order of reactivity with Cl2)
questions.explanation:
Option A :

I and II

Explanation :

Here, T2, D2, and P2 are isotopes of hydrogen (tritium, deuterium, and protium respectively).

I. T2 > D2 > P2 (order of boiling point) - This is correct. The boiling points of isotopes increase with increasing mass.

II. T2 > D2 > P2 (order of bond energy) - This is correct. Bond energy also tends to increase with increasing isotope mass. This is due to the stronger bonding in heavier isotopes.

III. T2 = D2 = P2 (order of bond length) - This is incorrect. The bond length decreases as the mass of the isotope increases. This means that the bond length of T2 (tritium) would be smaller than that of D2 (deuterium), which would be smaller than P2 (protium).

IV. T2 < D2 < P2 (order of reactivity with Cl2) - This is incorrect. The reactivity of hydrogen isotopes with halogens decreases as the isotope mass increases. So P2 would be more reactive than D2, which would be more reactive than T2.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Ninhydrin gives yellow colour in paper chromatography with which amino acid?
questions.explanation:
Option B : Proline

Explanation :

Ninhydrin is a chemical reagent commonly used to detect amino acids, peptides, and proteins. While most amino acids react with ninhydrin to give a purple-blue color, Proline and hydroxyproline are exceptions. These two amino acids react with ninhydrin to give a yellow color instead. This is because proline is a secondary amino acid, meaning its amino group is a part of a ring structure, which alters its reactivity compared to primary amino acids.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: How will raise in temperature affects the viscosity of liquids and gases?

options.content: In case of liquids, decreases and in case of gases, increases.
In case of liquid, increases and in case of gases, decreases.

questions.explanation:
Option C In case of liquids, decreases and in case of gases, increases.

Explanation :

Viscosity, in general, refers to a fluid's resistance to flow. It can be thought of as the internal friction between molecules in a fluid (liquids or gases).

For liquids, as temperature increases, the viscosity usually decreases. This is because at higher temperatures, the energy in the liquid is greater, allowing particles to move more easily and reducing the internal friction (or viscosity).

In contrast, for gases, as temperature increases, viscosity tends to increase. This is due to the fact that, in gases, increased temperatures lead to higher molecular speeds and more frequent collisions, effectively increasing the internal friction or viscosity.

$$pH = 7 + {{p{K_a}} \over 2} + {{\log C} \over 2}$$

where, C is concentration of salt.

Total volume of solution = 100 + 100 = 200 mL

Concentration of salt (C) $$ = 2 \times {{100} \over {200}} = 1$$ M

$$pH = 7 + {{3.74} \over 2} + {{\log [1]} \over 2}$$

$$pH = 7 + 1.87 + 0$$

$$pH = 8.87$$

questions.content:
Using the standard electrode potential, find out the pair between which redox reaction is not feasible.

E$$^\Theta $$ values Fe3+ / Fe2+ = + 0.77; I2 / I$$-$$ = + 0.54 Cu2+ / Cu = + 0.34; Ag+ / Ag = 0.80 V
questions.explanation:
(a) 2Fe3+ + 2e$$-$$ $$\to$$ 2Fe2+ ; E$$^\circ$$ = 0.77 V

2I$$-$$ $$\to$$ I2 + 2e$$-$$ ; E$$^\circ$$ = $$-$$0.54 V (sign of E$$^\circ$$ is reversed)

2Fe3+ + 2I$$-$$ $$\to$$ 2Fe2+ + I2 ; E$$_{cell}^o$$ = + 0.23 V

This reaction is feasible, since E$$_{cell}^o$$ is positive.

(b) Cu $$\to$$ Cu2+ + 2e$$-$$ ; E$$^\circ$$ = $$-$$ 0.34 V (sign of E$$^\circ$$ has been reversed)

2Ag+ + 2e$$-$$ $$\to$$ 2Ag ; E$$^\circ$$ = + 0.80 V

Cu + 2Ag+ $$\to$$ Cu2+ + 2Ag ; E$$^\circ$$ = + 0.46 V

This reaction is feasible, since E$$_{cell}^o$$ is positive.

(c) 2Fe3+ + 2e$$-$$ $$\to$$ 2Fe2+ ; E$$^\circ$$ = + 0.77 V

Cu $$\to$$ Cu2+ + 2e$$-$$ ; E$$^\circ$$ = $$-$$ 0.34 V (sign of E$$^\circ$$ is reversed)

2Fe3+ + Cu $$\to$$ 2Fe2+ + Cu2+ ; E$$^\circ$$ = + 0.43 V

This reaction is feasible, since E$$_{cell}^o$$ is positive.

(d) Ag $$\to$$ Ag+ + e$$-$$ ; E$$^\circ$$ = $$-$$ 0.80 V (sign of E$$^\circ$$ is reversed)

Fe3+ + e$$-$$ $$\to$$ Fe2+ ; E$$^\circ$$ = + 0.77 V

Ag + Fe3+ $$\to$$ Ag+ + Fe2+ ; E$$^\circ$$ = $$-$$ 0.03 V

This reaction is not feasible, since E$$_{cell}^o$$ is negative.

Adiabatic process, q = 0

Hence, when such a gas expands under adiabatic conditions into a vacuum, no heat is absorbed or evolved, since no external work is done to separate the molecules.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The given graph represents the variation of compressibility factor (Z) = $$\frac{pV}{nRT}$$, for three real gases A, B and C. Identify the only incorrect statement.

options.content: For the gas A, a = 0 and its dependence on p is linear at all pressure.
For the gas B, b = 0 and its dependence on p is linear at all pressure.
For the gas C, which is typical real gas for which neither a nor b = 0. By knowing the minima and point of the intersection with Z = 1, a and b can be calculated.
At high pressure the slope is positive for all real gases.

questions.explanation:
From the graph it is clear that, the value of 'Z' decreases with increase of pressure. We can explain as follows on the basis of van der Waals' equation.

At high pressure, when 'p' is large, V will be small and one cannot ignore 'b' in comparison to V. However, the team a/V2 may be considered negligible in comparison to 'p' in van der Waals' equation.

$$\left(p+\frac{a}{V^2}\right)$$ (V $$-$$ b) = nRT

p(V $$-$$ b) = nRT

$$\Rightarrow$$ pV $$-$$ pb = nRT

or $$\frac{pV}{nRT}=1+\frac{pb}{nRT}$$

or Z = 1 + $$\frac{pb}{nRT}$$

Thus, Z is greater than 1. As pressure is increased (at constant T), the factor $$\frac{pb}{nRT}$$ increases. This explains why after minima in the curves, Z increase continuously with pressure. Hence, the only incorrect statement is (b).

questions.content: 0.20 g of an organic compound gave 0.12 g of AgBr. By using Carius method, the percentage of bromine in the compound will be
questions.explanation:
Given,

Mass of an organic compound = 0.20 g

Mass of AgBr = 0.12 g

Molecular mass of AgBr = 188 g mol$$-$$1

188 g of AgBr contains 80 g of bromine

$$\therefore$$ 0.12 g of AgBr will contain = $$\frac{80}{188}$$ $$\times$$ 0.12 = 0.05 g of bromine

$$\therefore$$ Percentage of bromine = $$\frac{0.05}{0.20}$$ $$\times$$ 100 = 25%

questions.direction: Select the one which best exp resses the same sentence in Passive/Active voice.
questions.content: Then her face was bowed.

options.content: Then she was being bowed her face.
Her face was bowed by them.
Then her face has been bowed.

questions.explanation:
Option B : Her face was bowed by them.

The given sentence, "Then her face was bowed," is in the passive voice. The subject of the sentence (her face) is receiving the action (being bowed), and the doer of the action is not explicitly mentioned.

Option B, "Her face was bowed by them," provides the same meaning in the passive voice. It indicates that her face was bowed, and it specifies that the action was performed by "them" (the doer of the action).

The child is spoiled when the rod is spared.

questions.explanation:

The given sentence, "Spare the rod and spoil the child," is an idiom that implies that if discipline or punishment is not applied (spare the rod), the child will become undisciplined or spoiled.

Option D, "The child is spoiled when the rod is spared," accurately captures the meaning of the idiom by indicating that when the rod (disciplinary action) is spared, the child becomes spoiled.

questions.direction: Choose the word which is closest to the opposite in meaning of the given italicised word.
questions.content: The attack on the freedom of the press is a $$retrograde$$ step.
questions.explanation:
Option A : progressive

The word "retrograde" refers to moving backward or deteriorating to a previous, usually worse or less developed state. The term "progressive," on the other hand, suggests moving forward or advancing, often towards a better or more developed state. So, "progressive" is the term that is most nearly opposite in meaning to "retrograde."

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the word which is closest to the opposite in meaning of the given italicised word.
questions.content: The leader might have had some $$covert$$ reason for the change of his political affiliations.
questions.explanation:
The word "covert" is an adjective that suggests something is not openly acknowledged or displayed—in other words, something that is hidden or secret. When looking for a word that is closest to the opposite in meaning, we are seeking a term that implies openness or something being out in the open.

Here are the explanations of the given options:

  • Unjustifiable: This word means not able to be shown to be right or reasonable. It deals with the aspect of being defensible or not, rather than with visibility or secrecy.
  • Obvious: This word implies something that is easily perceived or understood; clear, self-evident, or apparent. It is synonymous with open or evident—therefore, it is a good candidate for a word that has an opposite meaning to "covert".
  • Inexplicable: This word describes something that cannot be explained or understood. While it may suggest a lack of understanding, it does not necessarily relate to the concept of being hidden or visible like "covert" does.
  • Flimsy: This word means something that is not strong or solid; lightly built or slight. It generally refers to the structural quality of an object or argument rather than its visibility or secrecy.

Given these definitions, the word closest in meaning to the opposite of "covert" is:

Option B: Obvious—because "obvious" directly contrasts with the idea of being hidden or secret, thereby providing an antonym for "covert".

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the order of the sentences marked A, B, C and D to form a logical paragraph.
questions.content:
(A) Now under liberated economy they are learning to compete domestically and globally.

(B) In India corporations until recently achieved success by avoiding competition, using protected and regulated domestic markets.

(C) The trend is irreversible.

(D) Business leaders are preparing themselves to meet competitive challenges, and to avoid being swept away.
questions.explanation:
Sentence B states that until recently, Indian corporations achieved success by avoiding competition and relying on protected and regulated domestic markets.

Sentence A fits logically after sentence B, as it mentions that now, under a liberated economy, businesses are learning to compete domestically and globally. This follows the shift mentioned in sentence B.

Sentence D can come next, as it states that business leaders are preparing themselves to meet competitive challenges and avoid being swept away. This connects to the changing dynamics mentioned in sentence A.

Finally, sentence C, which states that the trend is irreversible, can come last. It serves as a concluding statement that reinforces the idea that the shift towards competition and globalization is here to stay.

questions.subject: english-proficiency
questions.direction: Choose the order of the sentences marked A, B, C and D to form a logical paragraph.
questions.content:
(A) Recovery was given inadequate attention and consequently some bank branches regularly incurred heavy losses and their parent bodies had to bale them out.

(B) As a result, banks indulged in extensive lending to borrowers who had little or no potential to make repayments.

(C) To fulfil the social objectives laid down by the masters of nationalisation, banks were asked to lend to identified priority sectors.

(D) 1992-93 results showed that the loss making branches of public sector banks increased from 10000 to 13000 and the quantum of losses showed at Rs.3369 crores.
questions.explanation:
Sentence C provides the context by stating that banks were asked to lend to identified priority sectors to fulfill social objectives.

Sentence B logically follows sentence C, as it mentions the result of this policy, which is that banks indulged in extensive lending to borrowers who had little or no potential to make repayments. This follows the social objectives mentioned in sentence C.

Sentence A can come next, as it states that attention given to recovery (retrieving or collecting owed money) was not sufficient or lacking. This lack of attention resulted in bank branches regularly incurring heavy losses. This connects to the consequences mentioned in sentence B.

Finally, sentence D serves as a concluding statement, providing specific data and results about the increase in loss-making branches and the quantum of losses.

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.content:
'A + B' means 'A is the mother of B'.

'A $$-$$ B' means 'A is the brother of B'.

'A $$\times$$ B' means 'A is the father of B'.

'A $$\div$$ B' means 'A is the daughter of B'.

If, P $$-$$ K $$\times$$ Y $$-$$ J $$\div$$ S + R, then which of the following statement is not correct?

options.content: P is paternal uncle of R

questions.explanation:
The symbols represent different relationships as follows:

'A + B' means 'A is the mother of B'.

'A - B' means 'A is the brother of B'.

'A x B' means 'A is the father of B'.

'A ÷ B' means 'A is the daughter of B'.

Substituting these relationships into the given equation, P - K x Y - J ÷ S + R, yields :

P is the brother of K, who is the father of Y.

Y is the brother of J, who is the daughter of S.

S is the mother of R.

Now, let's check each statement :

Option A : K is the husband of S - Correct. If K is the father of Y and S is the mother of R, and both Y and R are siblings (since Y is the brother of J who is the daughter of S), K and S are married to each other.

Option B : Y is the son of S - Correct. As explained above, S is the mother of R, and since Y is a sibling of R, Y is the son of S.

Option C : J is the daughter of P - Incorrect. According to the relationships given, J is not related to P directly. J is the daughter of S, not P.

Option D : P is the paternal uncle of R - Correct. P is the brother of K who is the father of R, making P the paternal uncle of R.

So, the statement that is not correct is Option C : "J is the daughter of P".

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.content: The average marks of 50 students in a class was found to be 64. If the marks of two students were incorrectly entered as 38 and 42 instead of 83 and 24, respectively, then what is the correct average?
questions.explanation:
The initially computed average is based on incorrect entries. Let's first find the total sum of the marks of all 50 students using this incorrect average.

Total (Incorrect) = Average (Incorrect) Number of students = 64 50 = 3200

The incorrect entries were 38 and 42, whose sum is 80. The correct entries should have been 83 and 24, whose sum is 107.

Therefore, the difference between the incorrect total and the correct total is 107 - 80 = 27.

The correct total of all student marks should be the incorrect total plus this difference: 3200 + 27 = 3227.

Now we can compute the correct average:

Average (Correct) = Total (Correct) / Number of students = 3227 / 50 = 64.54

Therefore, the correct average is 64.54, which is Option A.

questions.content: Five friends A, B, C, D and E bought cars which were priced differently. B's car was costlier than C's car but was less costly than E's car. A's car was costlier than D's car but less costly than C's car. Whose car was the 2nd costliest?

From the given information, we can rank the cars as follows:

1. E's car is costlier than B's car.

2. B's car is costlier than C's car.

3. C's car is costlier than A's car.

4. A's car is costlier than D's car. So, the ranking of the cars from costliest to least costly is : E > B > C > A > D. Hence, B's car is the 2nd costliest.

questions.direction: In the following questions two statements are given followed by two conclusions I and II. You have to consider the two statements to be true even if they seem to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions, if any follow from the given statements.
questions.content:
Statements

60% of government employees went on strike.

Mr. Gopal is a government employee.

Conclusions

I. Mr. Gopal went on strike.

II. Mr. Gopal did not participate in the strike.

options.content: Both conclusions I and II follow
Either conclusion I or II follows

questions.explanation:
Option D : Either conclusion I or II follows

Based on the provided information, we know that 60% of government employees went on strike and Mr. Gopal is a government employee. However, it is not specified whether Mr. Gopal is part of the 60% that went on strike or the 40% that did not. Therefore, either conclusion I (Mr. Gopal went on strike) or conclusion II (Mr. Gopal did not participate in the strike) could be true.

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.direction: In the following question two statements are given followed by two conclusions I and II. You have to consider the two statements to be true even if they seem to be at variance from commonly known facts. You have to decide which of the given conclusions, if any follow from the given statements.
questions.content:
Statements

Lawyers marry only fair girls.

Shobha is very fair.

Conclusions

I. Shobha is married to a lawyer.

II. Shobha is not married to a lawyer.

options.content: Both conclusions I and II follow
Either conclusion I or II follows

questions.explanation:
Option D: Either conclusion I or II follows

The given statements don't provide definite information about whether Shobha is married to a lawyer or not. While the first statement says that lawyers marry only fair girls (which Shobha is), it does not mean that all fair girls marry lawyers. So, Shobha could be married to a lawyer (making conclusion I possible), or she could be married to someone who is not a lawyer (making conclusion II possible). Thus, either conclusion I or II could follow.

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.content:
Select the option in which the words share the same relationship as that shared by the given pair of words.

Barometer : Pressure
questions.explanation:
Option A : Ammeter : Current

The relationship in the given pair is that a barometer is a tool used to measure pressure. In the same way, an ammeter is a tool used to measure electric current. The other options do not reflect the correct relationships. A thermometer measures temperature, not volume; a voltmeter measures electrical potential difference, not heat; and a scale does not measure seconds. Therefore, the correct answer is Option A.

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.content:
Select the option in which the words share the same relationship as that shared by the given set of words.

Cat : Lion : Jaguar
questions.explanation:
Option C : Monkey : Chimpanzee : Gorilla

The words in the given set (Cat : Lion : Jaguar) are all types of mammals, more specifically, they belong to the Felidae (cat) family.

Looking at the options, the one that follows the same relationship is "Monkey : Chimpanzee : Gorilla". All of them are primates, a type of mammal.

Option A does not work because bat is a mammal while the other two are aquatic animals.

Option B does not work because sports is a general term, not a specific type of athlete or event.

Option D does not work because both snake and toad belong to different animal classifications (reptiles and amphibians, respectively).

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.content: 'Needle' is related to 'Sew' in the same way as 'Microscope' is related to '...........' .
questions.explanation:
Option D: Magnify

The relationship between 'Needle' and 'Sew' is that of a tool and its function, with the needle being a tool used for sewing. In the same way, a 'Microscope' is a tool used to 'Magnify' objects. So, the correct answer is 'Magnify'.

questions.subject: logical-reasoning
questions.content:
Select the letter-cluster that can replace the question mark (?) in the following series.

TXB, QWE, NVH, KUK, ?
questions.explanation:
1. The first letter of each cluster decreases by 3 positions in the alphabet: T (20th letter) to Q (17th letter) to N (14th letter) to K (11th letter), so the next should be H (8th letter).

2. The second letter of each cluster decreases by 1 position in the alphabet: X (24th letter) to W (23rd letter) to V (22nd letter) to U (21st letter), so the next should be T (20th letter).

3. The third letter of each cluster increases by 3 positions in the alphabet: B (2nd letter) to E (5th letter) to H (8th letter) to K (11th letter), so the next should be N (14th letter).

Therefore, the next letter cluster in the sequence should indeed be HTN, which is Option C.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If $$\alpha$$ be a root of the equation $$4{x^2} + 2x - 1 = 0$$, then the other root of the equation is
questions.explanation:
$$4{x^2} + 2x - 1 = 0$$

$$\therefore$$ $$\alpha + \beta = - {1 \over 2},\alpha \beta = - {1 \over 4}$$ ..... (i)

Also, $$4{\alpha ^2} + 2\alpha - 1 = 0$$ as $$\alpha$$ is a root and we have to prove that $$\beta = 4{\alpha ^3} - 3\alpha $$.

Now, $$4{\alpha ^3} - 3\alpha = 4{\alpha ^2}\,.\,\alpha - 3\alpha $$

$$ = \alpha (1 - 2\alpha ) - 3\alpha = - 2\alpha - 2\alpha $$

$$ = - {1 \over 2}[4{\alpha ^2} + 4\alpha ) = - {1 \over 2}[1 - 2\alpha + 4\alpha ]$$

$$ = - {1 \over 2}(1 + 2\alpha ) = - {1 \over 2} - \alpha = \beta $$

Now, $$\alpha + \beta = - {1 \over 2}$$ [from Eq. (i)]

Hence, $$\beta = 4{\alpha ^3} - 3\alpha $$.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If $$|w| = 2$$, then the set of points $$z = w - {1 \over w}$$ is contained in or equal to the set of points z satisfying
questions.explanation:
To solve this, we need to first express $$w$$ in the polar form since we know the modulus (or absolute value) of $$w$$.

$$w = |w|e^{iθ} = 2e^{iθ}$$

where $$θ$$ is the argument of $$w$$.

Substitute this into the expression for $$z$$:

$$z = w - {1 \over w} = 2e^{iθ} - {1 \over 2e^{iθ}}$$

By applying Euler's formula, which states that $$e^{iθ} = cos(θ) + isin(θ)$$, the expression becomes :

$$z = 2[cos(θ) + isin(θ)] - {1 \over 2}[cos(θ) - isin(θ)]$$

Simplify the expression :

$$z = [2cos(θ) - {1 \over 2}cos(θ)] + i[2sin(θ) + {1 \over 2}sin(θ)]$$

$$z = {3 \over 2}cos(θ) + {5 \over 2}isin(θ)$$

The modulus of $z$ can be found using the formula

$|z| = \sqrt{(Re(z))^2 + (Im(z))^2}$, where $Re(z)$ and $Im(z)$ are the real and imaginary parts of $z$, respectively.

So,

$|z| = \sqrt{(\frac{3}{2} \cos(θ))^2 + (\frac{5}{2} \sin(θ))^2} = \sqrt{(\frac{9}{4} \cos^2(θ)) + (\frac{25}{4} \sin^2(θ))}$

We know that $\sin^2(θ) + \cos^2(θ) = 1$ (based on the Pythagorean trigonometric identity), so let's replace $\cos^2(θ)$ with $1 - \sin^2(θ)$ in the equation above.

$|z| = \sqrt{(\frac{9}{4} (1 - \sin^2(θ))) + (\frac{25}{4} \sin^2(θ))}$

$= \sqrt{(\frac{9}{4} - \frac{9}{4} \sin^2(θ)) + (\frac{25}{4} \sin^2(θ))}$

$= \sqrt{\frac{9}{4} + \frac{16}{4} \sin^2(θ)}$

$= \sqrt{\frac{9 + 16 \sin^2(θ)}{4}}$

$ = \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{9 + 16 \sin^2(θ)}$

Now, $\sin^2(θ)$ is always less than or equal to 1, so $16 \sin^2(θ)$ is always less than or equal to 16.

So, the maximum value of $|z|$ is when $\sin^2(θ) = 1$, which makes $|z|$ equal to $\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{9 + 16} = \frac{1}{2} \sqrt{25} = \frac{5}{2}$.

So the set of points $z$ satisfying $|z| ≤ 3$ (Option D) includes all points $z$, and thus it is the correct choice.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The value of $$\mathop {\lim }\limits_{x \to 0} {{1-\cos (1 - \cos x)} \over {{x^4}}}$$ is
questions.explanation:
$$1 - \cos (1 - \cos x) = 2{\sin ^2}\left( {{{1 - \cos x} \over 2}} \right) = 2{\sin ^2}\left( {{{\sin }^2}{x \over 2}} \right)$$

$$\therefore$$ $$\mathop {\lim }\limits_{x \to 0} {{1-\cos (1 - \cos x)} \over {{x^4}}} = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{x \to 0} {{2{{\sin }^2}\left( {{{\sin }^2}{x \over 2}} \right)} \over {{x^4}}} = \mathop {\lim }\limits_{x \to 0} {{2{{\sin }^2}\left( {{{\sin }^2}{x \over 2}} \right)} \over {{{\left( {{{\sin }^2}{x \over 2}} \right)}^2}}} \times {{{{\sin }^4}{x \over 2}} \over {{{\left( {{x \over 2}} \right)}^2} \times 16}}$$

[$$\because$$ $$\mathop {\lim }\limits_{x \to 0} {{\sin x} \over x} = 1$$]

$$ = {1 \over 8}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Let a1, a2, ...... a40 be in AP and h1, h2, ..... h10 be in HP. If a1 = h1 = 2 and a10 = h10 = 3, then a4h7 is
questions.explanation:
Let d be the common difference of the AP. Then,

$${a_{10}} = 3 \Rightarrow {a_1} + 9d = 3$$

$$ \Rightarrow 2 + 9d = 3 \Rightarrow d = {1 \over 9}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${a_4} = {a_1} + 3d = 2 + {1 \over 3} = {7 \over 3}$$

Let D be the common difference of $${1 \over {{h_1}}},{1 \over {{h_2}}},\,...\, - {1 \over {{h_{10}}}}$$.

Then, $${h_{10}} = 3$$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {{h_{10}}}} = {1 \over 3} \Rightarrow {1 \over 2} + 9D = {1 \over 3}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 9D = - {1 \over 6} \Rightarrow D = - {1 \over {54}}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${1 \over {{h_7}}} = {1 \over {{h_1}}} + 6D = {1 \over 2} - {1 \over 9} = {7 \over {18}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {h_7} = {{18} \over 7}$$

$$\therefore$$ $${a_4}{h_7} = {7 \over 3} \times {{18} \over 7} = 6$$

questions.content: A running track of 440 ft is to be laid out enclosing a football field, the shape of which is a rectangle with a semi-circle at each end. If the area of the rectangular portion is to be maximum, then the lengths of its side are
questions.explanation:
Perimeter = 440 ft

$$\Rightarrow$$ 2x + $$\pi$$r + $$\pi$$r = 440

2x + 2$$\pi$$r = 440

A = Area of the rectangular portion = x2r

A = $$x\frac{(440-2x)}{\pi}=\frac{1}{\pi}(440x-2x^2)$$

Let $$\frac{dA}{dx}=\frac{1}{\pi}(440-4x)=0$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ x = 110 for which $$\frac{d^2A}{dx^2} < 0$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ A is maximum when x = 110

$$\Rightarrow$$ $$2r=\frac{440-2x}{\pi}=\frac{440-220}{22/7}=70$$

$$\therefore$$ r = 35 ft and x = 110 ft

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: $$\left( {{{dy} \over {dx}}} \right)\tan x = y{\sec ^2}x + \sin x$$, find general solution

options.content: $$y = \tan x(\log |{\mathop{\rm cosec}\nolimits} x - \cot x| + \cos x + c)$$

questions.explanation:
Given that

$$\left( {{{dy} \over {dx}}} \right)\tan x = y{\sec ^2}x + \sin x$$

$$\tan \left( {{{dy} \over {dx}}} \right) - y{\sec ^2}x = \sin x$$

$${{dy} \over {dx}} + \left( {{{ - {{\sec }^2}x} \over {\tan x}}} \right)y = {{\sin x} \over {\tan x}}$$

Here, $$P = - {{{{\sec }^2}x} \over {\tan x}}$$ and $$Q = \cos x$$

$$IF = {e^{\int {P\,dx} }} = {e^{\int {{{ - {{\sec }^2}x} \over {\tan x}}dx} }}$$

$$IF = {e^{ - \log (\tan x)}} = {e^{\log \cot x}} = \cot x$$

Now, $$y \times IF = \int {(Q \times IF)dx + C} $$

$$y\,.\,\cot x = \int {\cos x\,.\,\cot x + C} $$

$$y\,.\,\cot x = \int {{{1 - {{\sin }^2}x} \over {\sin x}} + C} $$

$$y\,.\,\cot x = \log |{\mathop{\rm cosec}\nolimits} \,x - \cot x| + \cos x + C$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If the straight line $$y = mx + c$$ touches the parabola $${y^2} - 4ax + 4{a^3} = 0$$, then c is
questions.explanation:
Solving the given equations,

$${(mx + c)^2} = 4ax - 4{a^3}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {m^2}{x^2} + 2mc\,.\,x + {c^2} = 4ax - 4{a^3}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {m^2}{x^2} + (2mc - 4a)x + {c^2} + 4{a^3} = 0$$

Since the straight line touches the parabola at a point, so, the discriminant = 0

$$ \Rightarrow {(2mc - 4a)^2} - 4{m^2}({c^2} + 4{a^3}) = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow 4{m^2}{c^2} - 16amc + 16{a^2} - 4{m^2}{c^2} - 16{a^3}{m^2} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow - mc + a - {a^2}{m^2} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow mc = a - {a^2}{m^2} \Rightarrow c = {a \over m} - {a^2}m$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: A normal is drawn at the point P to the parabola $${y^2} = 8x$$, which is inclined at 60$$^\circ$$ with the straight line $$y = 8$$. Then the point P lies on the straight line
questions.explanation:
For the parabola $${y^2} = 4ax$$, the equation of normal at $$P(a{m^2}, - 2am)$$ is $$y = mx - 2am - a{m^3}$$.

Here, $$m = \tan 60^\circ = \sqrt 3 $$

$$\therefore$$ $$P \equiv (a{(\sqrt 3 )^2}, - 2a(\sqrt 3 )) \equiv (6, - 4\sqrt 3 )$$ ($$\because$$ $$a = 2$$)

Thus, P satisfies $$2x - y - 12 - 4\sqrt 3 = 0$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: What is the area enclosed by the parabola described by $${(y - 2)^2} = (x - 1)$$, its tangent line at the point (2, 3), and the X-axis?
questions.explanation:
The equation of the parabola $${y^2} - 4y - x + 5 = 0$$

the equation of tangent at (2, 3) is

$$3y - 2(y + 3) - {{x + 2} \over 2} + 5 = 0$$

$$2y - x - 4 = 0$$

$$\therefore$$ Required area A is given by

$$A = \int_0^3 {({x_2} - {x_1})dy} $$

$$ \Rightarrow A = \int_0^3 {[\{ {{(y - 2)}^3} + 1\} - 2(2y - 4\} ]dy} $$

$$ \Rightarrow A = \int_0^3 {({y^2} - 6y + 9)dy = \int_0^3 {{{(3 - y)}^2}dy} } $$

$$ = - \left[ {{{{{(3 - y)}^3}} \over 3}} \right]_0^3 = 9$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: $$\widehat u$$ and $$\widehat v$$ are two non-collinear unit vectors such that $$\left| {{{\widehat u + \widehat v} \over 2} + \widehat u \times \widehat v} \right| = 1$$. Then the value of $$|\widehat u \times \widehat v|$$ is equal to
questions.explanation:
Given that, $$\left| {{{\widehat u + \widehat v} \over 2} + \widehat u \times \widehat v} \right| = 1$$

$$ \Rightarrow {\left| {{{\widehat u + \widehat v} \over 2} + \widehat u \times \widehat v} \right|^2} = 1$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{2 + 2\cos \theta } \over 4} + {\sin ^2}\theta = 1$$ [$$\because$$ $$\widehat u\,.\,(\widehat u \times \widehat v) = \widehat v(\widehat u \times \widehat v) = 0$$]

$$ \Rightarrow {\cos ^2}{\theta \over 2} = \cos 2\theta $$

$$ \Rightarrow \theta = n\pi \, \pm \,{\theta \over 2},\,n \in z$$

$$ \Rightarrow \theta = {{2\pi } \over 3}$$

$$ \Rightarrow \left| {\widehat u \times \widehat v} \right| = \sin {{2\pi } \over 3} = \sin {\pi \over 3} = \left| {{{\widehat u - \widehat v} \over 2}} \right|$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: A six faced die is a biased one. It is thrice more likely to show an odd numbers than show an even number. It is thrown twice. The probability that the sum of the numbers in two throws is even, is
questions.explanation:
Let P be the probability of getting an even number. Then by hypothesis the probability of getting an odd number is 3P. Since the events of getting an even number and an odd number are mutually exclusive and exhaustive.

$$\therefore$$ P + 3P = 1 $$\Rightarrow$$ P = 1/4

Thus, the probability of getting an odd number in a single throw is $$\frac{3}{4}$$ and that of an even number is $$\frac{1}{4}$$. If the die is thrown twice, then the sum of the numbers in two throws is even if both the numbers are even or both are odd.

$$\therefore$$ Required probability = $$\frac{3}{4}$$ $$\times$$ $$\frac{3}{4}$$ + $$\frac{1}{4}$$ $$\times$$ $$\frac{1}{4}$$ = $$\frac{10}{16}$$ = $$\frac{5}{8}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The sum of all the solution of the equation $$\cos \theta \cos \left( {{\pi \over 3} + \theta } \right)\cos \left( {{\pi \over 3} - \theta } \right) = {1 \over 4},\theta \in [0,6\pi ]$$
questions.explanation:
$$2\cos \theta [\cos 120^\circ + \cos 2\theta ] = 1$$

$$ \Rightarrow 2\cos \theta \left( { - {1 \over 2} + 2{{\cos }^2}\theta - 1} \right) = 1$$

$$ \Rightarrow 4{\cos ^3}\theta - 3\cos - 1 = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow \cos 3\theta = 1 = \cos 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow 3\theta = 2n\pi $$ or $$\theta = {{2n\pi } \over 3},n \in z$$

Given the values so that 2n does not exceed 18.

Hence, the sum $$ = {{2\pi } \over 3}\sum\limits_1^9 {n = {{2\pi } \over 3} \times {{9(9 + 1)} \over 2} = 30\pi } $$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Let $$\alpha$$ be the solution of $${16^{{{\sin }^2}\theta }} + {16^{{{\cos }^2}\theta }} = 10$$ in $$\left( {0,{\pi \over 4}} \right)$$. If the shadow of a vertical pole is $${1 \over {\sqrt 3 }}$$ of its height, then the altitude of the sun is
questions.explanation:
We have,

$${16^{{{\sin }^2}\theta }} + {16^{{{\cos }^2}\theta }} = 10$$

$$ \Rightarrow {16^{{{\sin }^2}\theta }} + {16^{1 - {{\sin }^2}\theta }} = 10$$

$$ \Rightarrow x + {{16} \over x} = 10$$, where $$x = {16^{{{\sin }^2}\theta }}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {x^2} - 10x + 16 = 0 \Rightarrow x = 2,8$$

$$\therefore$$ $${16^{{{\sin }^2}\theta }} = 2,8 \Rightarrow {2^{4{{\sin }^2}\theta }} = 2,{2^3}$$

$$ \Rightarrow 4{\sin ^2}\theta = 1,3 \Rightarrow {\sin ^2}\theta = {1 \over 4},{\left( {{{\sqrt 3 } \over 2}} \right)^2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow \sin \theta = {1 \over 2},{{\sqrt 3 } \over 2} \Rightarrow \theta = {\pi \over 6},{\pi \over 3}$$

Let the altitude of the sun be $$\theta$$. Then,

$$\tan \theta = {h \over {h/\sqrt 3 }} \Rightarrow \tan \theta = \sqrt 3 $$

$$ \Rightarrow \theta = \pi /3 \Rightarrow \theta = 2\alpha $$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: For each parabola y = x2 + px + q, meeting coordinate axes at 3-distinct points, if circles are drawn through these points, then the family of circles must pass through
questions.explanation:
Suppose the parabola, y = x2 + px + q cuts X-axis at A($$\alpha$$, 0) and B($$\beta$$, 0).

Then, $$\alpha$$, $$\beta$$ are roots of the equation x2 + px + q = 0

$$\therefore$$ $$\alpha$$ + $$\beta$$ = $$-$$p and $$\alpha \beta$$ = q

The parabola y - x2 + px + q cuts Y-axis at (0, q).

Let the equation of the circle passing through A, B and C be

x2 + y2 + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0 .... (i)

$$\therefore$$ $$\alpha$$2 + 2g$$\alpha$$ + c = 0 ..... (ii)

$$\beta$$2 + 2g$$\beta$$ + c = 0 ...... (iii)

and q2 + 2fq + c = 0 ..... (iv)

Subtracting Eq. (iii) from Eq. (ii), we get

$$\alpha + \beta + 2g = 0$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ g = p/2

Adding Eqs. (ii) and (iii), we get

$$\alpha^2+\beta^2+2g(\alpha+\beta)+2c=0$$

$$(\alpha+\beta)^2-2\alpha \beta+2g(\alpha+\beta)+2c=0$$

p2 $$-$$ 2q $$-$$ p2 + 2c = 0 [$$\because$$ $$\alpha+\beta=p$$ and g = $$\frac{p}{2}$$]

Putting c = q in Eq. (iv), we get f = $$-$$$$\left(\frac{q+1}{2}\right)$$

Substituting the values of g, f and c in Eq. (i), we obtain the equation of family of circles passing through A, B and C as

x2 + y2 + px $$-$$ (q + 1) y + q = 0

Clearly, it passes through (0, 1).

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The number of ways of arranging letters of the word HAVANA so that V and N do not appear together is
questions.explanation:
The word HAVANA has 6 letters. However, the letters 'A' appear 3 times. We'll first consider all permutations, and then subtract the ones where 'V' and 'N' appear together.

1. Total permutations :

Since we have 6 total letters and 3 of them are the same (A), we use the formula for permutations of multiset to get the total number of arrangements, which is 6! / 3! = 720 / 6 = 120.

2. Permutations with 'V' and 'N' together :

Let's consider 'V' and 'N' as a single entity. So, we have 5 entities - {V,N}, 'A', 'A', 'A', 'H'.

Since 'A' appears 3 times, the total permutations would be 5! / 3! = 120 / 6 = 20.

However, 'V' and 'N' can be arranged among themselves in 2! = 2 ways.

So, total arrangements where 'V' and 'N' are together is 20 $$ \times $$ 2 = 40.

The total permutations where 'V' and 'N' do not appear together is the total permutations minus the ones where they are together: 120 - 40 = 80.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Let a1, a2, a3 .... be a harmonic progression with a1 = 5 and a20 = 25. The least positive integer n for which an < 0, is
questions.explanation:
It is given that a1, a2, a3 .... are in HP.

Therefore, $${1 \over {{a_1}}},{1 \over {{a_2}}},{1 \over {{a_3}}}$$, ..... are in AP

Let d be the common difference of the AP.

$$\therefore$$ $${1 \over {{a_n}}} = {1 \over {{a_1}}} + (n - 1)d$$ and $${1 \over {{a_{20}}}} = {1 \over {{a_1}}} + 19d$$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {{a_n}}} = {1 \over 5} + (n - 1)d$$ and $${1 \over {25}} = {1 \over 5} + 19d$$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {{a_n}}} = {1 \over 5} + (n - 1)d$$ and $$d = {{ - 4} \over {19 \times 25}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {{a_n}}} = {1 \over 5} - {{4(n - 1)} \over {19 \times 25}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {{a_n}}} = {{95 - 4n + 4} \over {19 \times 25}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {a_n} = {{99 - 4n} \over {19 \times 25}}$$

Now, $${a_n} < 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{99 - 4n} \over {19 \times 25}} < 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow 99 - 4n < 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow 4n > 99$$

$$ \Rightarrow n > 24{3 \over 4} \Rightarrow n \ge 25$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If the plane $$3x + y + 2z + 6 = 0$$ is parallel to the line $${{3x - 1} \over {2b}} = 3 - y = {{z - 1} \over a}$$, then the value of $$3a + 3b$$ is
questions.explanation:
Given plane $$3x + y + 2z + 6 = 0$$

and line $${{x - {1 \over 3}} \over {{{2b} \over 3}}} = {{y - 3} \over { - 1}} = {{z - 1} \over a}$$

Since, plane is parallel to line, then

$$3\left( {{{2b} \over 3}} \right) + (1)( - 1) + 2(a) = 0$$

$$2b - 1 + 2a = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow a + b = {1 \over 2}$$

Now, $$3a + 3b = {3 \over 2}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Let a, b be the solutions of x2 + px + 1 = 0 and c, d be the solution of x2 + qx + 1 = 0. If (a $$-$$ c) (b $$-$$ c) and (a + d)(b + d) are the solution of x2 + ax + $$\beta$$ = 0, then $$\beta$$ is equal to
questions.explanation:
Since, a + b = $$-$$p, ab = 1 ..... (i)

and c + d = $$-$$q, cd = 1

Now, (a $$-$$ c) (b $$-$$ c) and (a + d) (b + d) are the roots of x2 + ax + $$\beta$$ = 0

(a $$-$$ c) (b $$-$$ c) (a + d) (b + d) = $$\beta$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ (ab $$-$$ ac $$-$$ bc + c2) (ab + ad + bd + d2) = $$\beta$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ {1 $$-$$ c (a + b) + c2} {1 + d(a + b) + d2} = $$\beta$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ (1 + pc + c2)(1 $$-$$ pd + d2) = $$\beta$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ 1 $$-$$ pd + d2 + pc $$-$$ p2cd + pcd2 + c2 $$-$$ pc2d + c2d2 = $$\beta$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ 1 $$-$$ pd + d2 + pc $$-$$ p2 + pd + c2 $$-$$ pc + 1 = $$\beta$$ [$$\because$$ cd = 1]

$$\Rightarrow$$ 2 + d2 + c2 $$-$$ p2 = $$\beta$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ 2cd + c2 + d2 $$-$$ p2 = $$\beta$$

(c + d)2 $$-$$ p2 = $$\beta$$

q2 $$-$$ p2 = $$\beta$$ [$$\because$$ (c + d) = $$-$$ q]

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If $$\left[ {\matrix{ 1 & { - \tan \theta } \cr {\tan \theta } & 1 \cr } } \right]{\left[ {\matrix{ 1 & {\tan \theta } \cr { - \tan \theta } & 1 \cr } } \right]^{ - 1}} = \left[ {\matrix{ a & { - b} \cr b & a \cr } } \right]$$, then
questions.explanation:
Given,

$$\left[ {\matrix{ 1 & { - \tan \theta } \cr {\tan \theta } & 1 \cr } } \right]{\left[ {\matrix{ 1 & {\tan \theta } \cr { - \tan \theta } & 1 \cr } } \right]^{ - 1}} = \left[ {\matrix{ a & { - b} \cr b & a \cr } } \right]$$

$$ \Rightarrow \left[ {\matrix{ 1 & { - \tan \theta } \cr {\tan \theta } & 1 \cr } } \right]\,.\,{1 \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}\theta }}\left[ {\matrix{ 1 & { - \tan \theta } \cr {\tan \theta } & 1 \cr } } \right] = \left[ {\matrix{ a & { - b} \cr b & a \cr } } \right]$$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}\theta }}\left[ {\matrix{ {1 - {{\tan }^2}\theta } & { - 2\tan \theta } \cr {2\tan \theta } & {1 - {{\tan }^2}\theta } \cr } } \right] = \left[ {\matrix{ a & { - b} \cr b & a \cr } } \right]$$

$$ \Rightarrow \left[ {\matrix{ {{{1 - {{\tan }^2}\theta } \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}\theta }}} & {{{2\tan \theta } \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}\theta }}} \cr {{{2\tan \theta } \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}\theta }}} & {{{1 - {{\tan }^2}\theta } \over {1 + {{\tan }^2}\theta }}} \cr } } \right] = \left[ {\matrix{ a & { - b} \cr b & a \cr } } \right]$$

$$ \Rightarrow \left[ {\matrix{ {\cos 2\theta } & { - \sin 2\theta } \cr {\sin 2\theta } & {\cos 2\theta } \cr } } \right] = \left[ {\matrix{ a & { - b} \cr b & a \cr } } \right]$$

$$ \Rightarrow a = \cos 2\theta ,b = \sin 2\theta $$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The locus of the mid-point of the chord if contact of tangents drawn from points lying on the straight line $$4x - 5y = 20$$ to the circle $${x^2} + {y^2} = 9$$ is
questions.explanation:
Let $$P\left( {t,{{4t - 20} \over 5}} \right)$$ be a point on the line $$4x - 5y = 20$$. Then the chord of contact of tangents drawn from P to the circle $${x^2} + {y^2} = 9$$ is

$$tx + \left( {{{4t - 20} \over 5}} \right)y = 9$$ ...... (i)

Let $$\theta$$ (h, k) be the mid-point of this chord of contact, then its equation is also $$hx + ky = {h^2} + {k^2}$$ ..... (ii) [using $$T = S'$$]

Clearly Eqs. (i) and (ii) represent the same line

$$\therefore$$ $${t \over h} = {{4t - 20} \over {5k}} = {9 \over {{h^2} + {k^2}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {t \over h} = {9 \over {{h^2} + {k^2}}}$$ and $${t \over h} = {{4t - 20} \over {5k}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow t = {{9h} \over {{h^2} + {k^2}}}$$ and $$t = {{20h} \over {4h - 5k}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{9h} \over {{h^2} + {k^2}}} = {{20h} \over {4h - 5k}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow h\{ 20({h^2} + {k^2}) - 36h + 45k\} = 0$$

$$x = 0$$ or $$[20({x^2} + {y^2}) - 36x + 45y] = 0$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Let $$f(x) = \int {{{{x^2}dx} \over {(1 + {x^2})(1 + \sqrt {1 + {x^2}} )}}} $$ and $$f(0) = 0$$, then the value of $$f(1)$$ be
questions.explanation:
$$f(x) = \int {{{{x^2}dx} \over {(1 + {x^2})(1 + \sqrt {1 + {x^2}} )}}} $$

Let $$x = \tan \theta $$

$$ \Rightarrow dx = {\sec ^2}\theta d\theta = (1 + {x^2})d\theta $$

$$f(x) = \int {{{{x^2}dx} \over {(1 + {x^2})(1 + \sqrt {1 + {x^2}} )}}} $$

$$ = \int {{{{{\tan }^2}\theta {{\sec }^2}\theta d\theta } \over {{{\sec }^2}\theta (1 + \sec \theta )}} = \int {{{{{\tan }^2}\theta d\theta } \over {1 + \sec \theta }}} } $$

$$ = \int {{{{{\sin }^2}\theta d\theta } \over {\cos \theta (1 + \cos \theta )}}} $$

$$ = \int {{{1 - {{\cos }^2}\theta d\theta } \over {\cos \theta (1 + \cos \theta )}}} $$

$$ = \int {{{(1 - \cos \theta )d\theta } \over {\cos \theta }}} $$

$$ = \int {\sec \theta d\theta - \int {d\theta } } $$

$$ = \log (x + \sqrt {1 + {x^2}} ) - {\tan ^{ - 1}}x + C$$

$$\therefore$$ $$f(0) = \log (0 + \sqrt {1 + 0} ) - {\tan ^{ - 1}}(0) + C$$

$$0 = \log 1 - 0 + C$$

$$ \Rightarrow C = 0$$

$$\therefore$$ $$f(1) = \log (1 + \sqrt {1 + {1^2}} ) - {\tan ^{ - 1}}(1)$$

$$ = \log (1 + \sqrt 2 ) - {\pi \over 4}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The mean of five observations is 4 and their variance is 5.2. If three of these observations are 1, 2 and 6, then the other two are
questions.explanation:
Let the two unknown items be x and y. Then,

Mean $$ = 4 \Rightarrow {{1 + 2 + 6 + x + y} \over 5} = 4$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ x + y = 11 ..... (i)

and variance = 5.2

$$ \Rightarrow {{{1^2} + {2^2} + {6^2} + {x^2} + {y^2}} \over 5}$$ $$-$$ (mean)2 = 5.2

$$\Rightarrow$$ 41 + x2 + y2 = 5(5.2 + 16)

$$\Rightarrow$$ 41 + x2 + y2 = 106

$$\Rightarrow$$ x2 + y2 = 65 ..... (ii)

On solving Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

x = 4, y = 7 or x = 7, y = 4

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: In a sequence of 21 terms, the first 11 terms are in AP with common difference 2 and the last 11 terms are in GP with common ratio 2. If the middle term of AP be equal to the middle term of the GP, then the middle term of the entire sequence is
questions.explanation:
Since, the first 11 terms are in AP, d = 2

$$\therefore$$ a11 = a + 10d = a + 20

the middle term of AP is

T6 = a + 5d = a + 10

For the next 11 terms in GP

r = 2

$$\therefore$$ The middle term of GP is b(2)5 where b is the first term of a GP which is the last term of AP

b(2)5 = (a + 20) 32

According to the given condition,

$$\Rightarrow$$ a + 10 = (a + 20) 32

$$\Rightarrow$$ 31a = 10 $$-$$ 640

a = $$-\frac{630}{31}$$

$$\therefore$$ Middle term of entire sequence is 11th term

$$\therefore$$ T11 = $$\frac{-630}{31}+10\times d$$

$$=\frac{-630}{31}+10\times 2 =\frac{-10}{31}$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content:
If p $$\ne$$ a, q $$\ne$$ b, r $$\ne$$ c and the system of equations

px + ay + az = 0

bx + qy + bz = 0

cx + cy + rz = 0

has a non-trivial solution, then the value of $$\frac{p}{p-a}+\frac{q}{q-b}+\frac{r}{r-c}$$ is
questions.explanation:
As the given system of equations has a non-trivial solution.

$$\Delta = \left| {\matrix{ p & a & a \cr b & q & b \cr c & c & r \cr } } \right| = 0$$

Applying $${C_2} \to {C_2} - {C_1}$$ and $${C_3} \to {C_3} - {C_1}$$

$$\Delta = \left| {\matrix{ p & {a - p} & {a - p} \cr b & {q - b} & 0 \cr c & 0 & {r - c} \cr } } \right| = 0$$

Expanding along C3, we get

$$(a - p)\left| {\matrix{ b & {q - b} \cr c & 0 \cr } } \right| + (r - c)\left| {\matrix{ p & {a - p} \cr b & {q - b} \cr } } \right| = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow (a - p)( - c)(q - b) + (r - c)\{ p(q - b) - b(a - p)\} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow (p - a)(q - b)c + p(r - c)(q - b) + b(r - c)(p - a) = 0$$

Dividing $$(p - a)(q - b)(r - c)$$, we get

$${c \over {r - c}} + {p \over {p - a}} + {b \over {q - b}} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow {p \over {p - a}} + {q \over {q - b}} + {r \over {r - c}} = {{q - b} \over {q - b}} + {{r - c} \over {r - c}} = 2$$

questions.content: The smallest positive integral value of n such that $${\left[ {{{1 + \sin {\pi \over 8} + i\cos {\pi \over 8}} \over {1 + \sin {\pi \over 8} - i\cos {\pi \over 8}}}} \right]^n}$$ is purely imaginary, is equal to
questions.explanation:
$${\left[ {{{1 + \sin {\pi \over 8} + i\cos {\pi \over 8}} \over {1 + \sin {\pi \over 8} - i\cos {\pi \over 8}}}} \right]^n} = {\left[ {{{1 + \cos \alpha + i\sin \alpha } \over {1 + \cos \alpha - i\sin \alpha }}} \right]^n}$$ [$$\because$$ $$\alpha = {\pi \over 2} - {\pi \over 8}$$]

$$ = {\left[ {{{2{{\cos }^2}{\alpha \over 2} + 2i\sin {\alpha \over 2}\cos {\alpha \over 2}} \over {2{{\cos }^2}{\alpha \over 2} - 2i\sin {\alpha \over 2}\cos {\alpha \over 2}}}} \right]^n}$$

$$ = \left[ {{{\cos {\alpha \over 2} + i\sin {\alpha \over 2}} \over {\cos {\alpha \over 2} - i\sin {\alpha \over 2}}}} \right]_ - ^n = {\left( {{e^{2t{\alpha \over 2}}}} \right)^n} = {e^{in\,\alpha }}$$

$$ = {e^{in\left( {{{3\pi } \over 8}} \right)}} = \cos {{3n\pi } \over 8} + i\sin {{3n\pi } \over 8}$$

For n = 4 we get imaginary part.

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: Given that a house forms a right angle view from a window of another house, and the angle of elevation from the base of the first house to the window is 60 degrees. If the separation between the two houses is 6 meters, calculate the height of the first house.
questions.explanation:
Let PQ be the house subtending a right angle at the window B of opposite house AB

In $$\Delta$$PAB, we have

tan60$$^\circ$$ = $$\frac{AB}{6}$$ = AB = 6$$\sqrt3$$ m

In $$\Delta$$CBQ, we have

$$\tan 30^\circ = {{h - CP} \over {BC}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {1 \over {\sqrt 3 }} = {{h - 6\sqrt 3 } \over 6}$$ [$$\because$$ $$AB = CP,BC = AP$$]

$$ \Rightarrow h = 6\left( {\sqrt 3 + {1 \over {\sqrt 3 }}} \right)$$

$$ \Rightarrow h = 8\sqrt 3 $$ m

questions.content: A spherical balloon is filled with 4500$$\pi$$ cubic meters of helium gas. If a leak in the balloon causes the gas to escape at the rate of 72$$\pi$$ cubic meters per minute then the rate (in meters per minute) at which the radius of the balloon decreases 49 min after the leakage began is
questions.explanation:
V = $$\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\Rightarrow4500\pi=\frac{4\pi r^3}{3}$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ r = 15 m

After 49 min = (4500 $$-$$ 49.72) $$\pi$$

= 972 $$\pi$$m3

$$\Rightarrow$$ 972$$\pi=\frac{4}{3}\pi r^3$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ r3 = 3 $$\times$$ 243 = 3 $$\times$$ 35

r = 9

$$\frac{dv}{dt}=4 \pi r^2\left(\frac{dr}{dt}\right)$$

72$$\pi$$ = 4$$\pi$$ $$\times$$ 9 $$\times$$ $$\left(\frac{dr}{dt}\right)$$

$$\frac{dr}{dt}=\left(\frac{2}{9}\right)$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: The area enclosed by the curves $$y = \sin x + \cos x$$ and $$y = |\cos x - \sin x|$$ over the interval $$\left[ {0,{\pi \over 2}} \right]$$ is
questions.explanation:
Given, $$y = \sin x + \cos x,\,\,x \in [0,\pi /2]$$

$${{dy} \over {dx}} = \cos x - \sin x$$

$$y = |\cos x - \sin x|$$

$$ = \left[ {\matrix{ {\cos x - \sin x} & {x \in [0,\pi /4]} \cr {\sin x - \cos x} & {x \in [\pi /4,\pi /2]} \cr } } \right]$$

$$\therefore$$ Required area

$$ = \int_0^{\pi /4} {|(\sin x + \cos x) - (\cos x - \sin x)|dx + \int_{\pi /4}^{\pi /2} {|2\cos x|dx} } $$

$$ = \int_0^{\pi /4} {|2\sin x|dx + \int_{\pi /4}^{\pi /2} {|2\cos x|dx} } $$

$$ = 2( - \cos x)_0^{\pi /4} + 2(\sin x)_{\pi /4}^{\pi /2}$$

$$ = 2\left[ { - {1 \over {\sqrt 2 }} + 1 + 1 - {1 \over {\sqrt 2 }}} \right]$$

$$ = 2\left( {2 - {2 \over {\sqrt 2 }}} \right)$$

$$ = 2(2 - \sqrt 2 )$$

$$ = 4 - 2\sqrt 2 $$

$$ = 2\sqrt 2 (\sqrt 2 - 1)$$

questions.subject: mathematics
questions.content: If $$\alpha,\beta,\gamma \in[0,\pi]$$ and if $$\alpha,\beta,\gamma$$ are in AP, then $${{\sin \alpha - \sin \gamma } \over {\cos \gamma - \cos \alpha }}$$ is equal to
questions.explanation:
$${{\sin \alpha - \sin \gamma } \over {\cos \gamma - \cos \alpha }} = {{2\cos {{\alpha + \gamma } \over 2}\sin {{\alpha - \gamma } \over 2}} \over {2\sin {{\alpha + \gamma } \over 2}\,.\,\sin {{\alpha - \gamma } \over 2}}} = \cot {{\alpha + \gamma } \over 2}$$

[$$\because$$ $$\sin A - \sin B = 2\cos \left( {{{A + B} \over 2}} \right)\sin \left( {{{A - B} \over 2}} \right)$$ and $$\cos A - \cos B = 2\sin \left( {{{A + B} \over 2}} \right)\sin \left( {{{B - A} \over 2}} \right)$$]

But $$\alpha,\beta,\gamma$$ are in AP

$$ \Rightarrow {{\alpha + \gamma } \over 2} = \beta $$

So, required value is cot $$\beta$$.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In a resonance coloum first and second resonance are obtained at depths 24 cm and 78 cm the third resonance will be obtained at depth.
questions.explanation:
Given, first resonance column at depth, $${l_1} = 24$$ cm

Second resonance column at depth, $${l_2} = 78$$ cm

Third resonance column at depth, $${l_3} = ?$$

As

$${l_1} + x = {\lambda \over 4} = 24$$ ..... (i)

$${l_2} + x = {{3\lambda } \over 4} = 78$$ ........ (ii)

$${l_3} + x = {{5\lambda } \over 4}$$ ........ (iii)

From Eqs. (i) and (ii),

$$x = {{{l_2} - 3{l_1}} \over 2} = {{78 - 3(24)} \over 2} = 3$$ ....... (iv)

From Eqs. (iii) and (i), $${{{l_3} + x} \over {{l_1} + x}} = 5$$

$${l_3} = 5{l_1} + 5x - x = 5{l_1} + 4x$$

Substituting $$l_1$$ and x value, we get

$${l_3} = 5(24) + 4(3) \Rightarrow {l_3} = 132$$ cm.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
A submarine A travelling at 17 m/s is being chased along the line of its velocity by another submarine B travelling at 34 m/s. B sends a sonar signal of 600 Hz to detect A and receives a reflected sound of frequency $$\nu$$. The of $$\nu$$ is

[Speed of sound in water = 1500 ms$$-$$1]
questions.explanation:
Given, velocity of submarine A, vA = 17 m/s

Velocity of submarine B, vB = 34 m/s

Signal sent by submarine B is detected by submarine A can be shown as

Frequency of signal, f0 = 600 Hz

Speed of sound in water vs = 1500 ms$$-$$1

Frequency received by submarine A is

$${f_1} = \left( {{{{v_s} - {v_A}} \over {{v_s} - {v_B}}}} \right){f_0} = \left[ {{{1500 - 17} \over {1500 - 34}}} \right] \times 600$$ Hz

$${f_1} = {{1483} \over {1466}} \times 600$$ ..... (i)

Frequency received by submarine B is

$${f_2} = \left( {{{{v_s} + {v_B}} \over {{v_s} + {v_A}}}} \right){f_1}$$

Substituting given values and f1 value from Eq. (i), we get

$${f_2} = \left( {{{1500 + 34} \over {1500 + 17}}} \right) \times \left[ {{{1483} \over {1466}} \times 600} \right]$$

$${f_2} = 1.0112 \times 1.0115 \times 600$$

$${f_2} = 613.7$$ Hz.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Transverse waves of the same frequency are generated in two steel wires A and B. The diameter of A is twice that of B and the tension in A is half that in B. The ratio of the velocities of the waves in A and B is
questions.explanation:
The velocity of transverse waves is given by $$v = \sqrt {{T \over m}} $$ where, T = Tension and m = mass per unit length of the wire. If r is the radius of the wire and $$\rho$$ its density then,

$$m = \pi {r^2}\rho $$

$$\therefore$$ $$v = \sqrt {{T \over m}} = \sqrt {{T \over {\pi {r^2}\rho }}} $$

$$\therefore$$ $${v_A} = {{\sqrt {{T_A}} } \over {{r_A}\sqrt {\pi \rho } }}$$ and

$${v_B} = {{\sqrt {{T_B}} } \over {{r_B}\sqrt {\pi \rho } }}$$

Now, $${{{v_A}} \over {{v_B}}} = \sqrt {{{{T_A}} \over {{T_B}}}} .\,{{{r_B}} \over {{r_A}}}$$

$$\because$$ $${r_A} = 2{r_B}$$ and $${T_A} = {1 \over 2}{T_B}$$

Hence, $${{{v_A}} \over {{v_B}}} = {1 \over {2\sqrt 2 }}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In the diagram shown below, both the strings AB and CD are made of same material and have same cross-section. The pulleys are light and fictionless. If the speed of wave in string AB is v1 and in CD is v2, then $${{{v_1}} \over {{v_2}}}$$ is
questions.explanation:
Let the speed of wave in string be v and tension in string be T.

$$v \propto \sqrt T $$

$${{{v_{AB}}} \over {{v_{CD}}}} = \sqrt {{T \over {2T}}} = {1 \over {\sqrt 2 }}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: What will be the acceleration due to gravity at a depth d, where g is acceleration due to gravity on the surface of earth?
questions.explanation:
Acceleration due to gravity at the surface of earth,

$$g = {{GM} \over {{R^2}}} = {4 \over 3}\pi \rho GR$$ ...... (i)

[$$\because$$ $$M = {4 \over 3}\pi {R^3}\,.\rho $$]

Where, $$\rho$$ = density of earth.

Acceleration due to gravity at depth d from the surface of earth,

$$g' = {4 \over 3}\pi \rho G(R - d)$$ ...... (ii)

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get,

$$g' = g\left[ {1 - {d \over R}} \right]$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A direct current of 6 A is superimposed on an alternating current I = 10 sin $$\omega$$t flowing through a wire. The effective value of the resulting current will be
questions.explanation:
Given, $$I = 6 + 10\sin \omega t$$

$${I_{eft}} = \left[ {{{\int\limits_0^T {{I^2}dt} } \over {\int\limits_0^T {dt} }}} \right] = {\left[ {{1 \over T}\int\limits_0^T {{{(6 + 10\sin \omega t)}^2}dt} } \right]^{1/2}}$$

$$ = {\left[ {{1 \over T}\int\limits_0^T {(36 + 120\sin \omega t + 100{{\sin }^2}\omega t)dt} } \right]^{1/2}}$$

But as, $${1 \over T}\int\limits_0^T {\sin \omega t\,dt = 0} $$ and $${1 \over T}\int\limits_0^T {{{\sin }^2}\omega t = {1 \over 2}} $$

$$ \Rightarrow {I_{eff}} = {\left[ {36 + {1 \over 2} \times 100} \right]^{1/2}} = 9.27$$

Thus, $${I_{eff}} = 9.27\,A$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A machine gun fires 300 bullets per min if the mass of each bullet is 10 g and the velocity of the bullets is 600 ms$$-$$1, the power (in kW) of the gun is
questions.explanation:
work done by the gun = total kinetic energy of the bullets

$$ = n{1 \over 2}m{v^2} = 300 \times {1 \over 2} \times 10 \times {10^{ - 3}} \times {(600)^2}$$

$$ = 150 \times 10 \times {10^{ - 3}} \times 600 \times 600$$

Power of gun $$ = {{work\,done} \over {Time\,taken}}$$

$$ = {{150 \times 10 \times {{10}^{ - 3}} \times 600 \times 600} \over {60\,s}}$$

= 9 kW ($$\because$$ 1 minute = 60 seconds)

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Four holes of radius 5 cm are cut from a thin square plate of 20 cm and mass 1 kg. The moment of inertia of the remaining portion about Z-axis is
questions.explanation:
Area mass density, $$\sigma = {M \over {16{R^2}}}$$ ($$\because$$ Area = $$4R \times 4R = 16{R^2}$$)

Mass of each hole $${m_1} = \sigma \pi {R^2} = {M \over {16{R^2}}}\pi {R^2} = {{\pi M} \over {16}}$$

Distance between centre of plate and centre of hole

$$x = {{\sqrt {{{(2R)}^2} + {{(2R)}^2}} } \over 2} = {{2\sqrt 2 R} \over 2}$$

Moment of inertia of one hole at about Z-axis

$${I_1} = {1 \over 2}{m_1}{R^2} + {m_1}{x^2} = {{5\pi } \over {32}}M{R^2}$$

Moment of inertia of whole plate about Z-axis

$$I = {{M{{(4R)}^2}} \over 6} = {8 \over 3}M{R^2}$$

Required moment of inertia

$${I_0} = I - 4{I_1},$$ $$ = \left[ {{8 \over 3} - 4\left( {{{5\pi } \over {32}}} \right)} \right]M{R^2} = \left[ {{8 \over 3} - {{5\pi } \over 8}} \right]M{R^2}$$

Given, R = 5 cm and M = 1 kg

So, $${I_0} = \left[ {{8 \over 3} - {{5\pi } \over 8}} \right]1 \times 25 \times {10^{ - 4}} = 0.0017$$ kg-m2

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A particle of mass m is projected with velocity v at an angle $$\theta$$ with the horizontal. At its highest point, it explodes into two pieces of equal mass, one of the piece continue to move on the original trajectory, then the velocity of second piece is
questions.explanation:
According to the law of conservation of linear momentum at the highest point,

$$mv\cos \theta = {m \over 2}(v\cos \theta ) + {m \over 2}v'$$

$$ \Rightarrow mv\cos \theta - {m \over 2}v\cos \theta = {m \over 2}v'$$

$$ \Rightarrow v' = 2\left( {v\cos \theta - {{v\cos \theta } \over 2}} \right) = v\cos \theta $$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In the circuit shown assume the diode to be ideal. When Vi increases from $$-$$2V to 6V, the change in current is (in mA)
questions.explanation:
$${l_{initial}} = 0$$ for $${V_i} \le \,+ 1\,V$$

This diode conduct only beyond $${V_i} = \, + 1\,V$$

$${I_{final}} = {5 \over {250}} = 0.02\,A$$

So, change in $$I = 0.02\,A = 20\,mA$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The de-Broglie wavelength of an electron moving with a velocity $$\frac{c}{3}$$ (c = 3 $$\times$$ 108 m/s) is equal to the wavelength of photon. The ratio of the kinetic energies of electron and photon is
questions.explanation:
The de-Broglie wavelength, $$\lambda = {h \over {mv}}$$

Here, $${\lambda _e} = {h \over {{m_e}{e \over 3}}}$$ and $${\lambda _p} = {h \over {{m_p}c}}$$

Given, $${\lambda _e} = {\lambda _p}$$

So, $${h \over {{m_e}{c \over 3}}} = {h \over {{m_p}c}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{m_e}} \over {{m_p}}} = 3$$

Ratio of $$KE = {{{K_e}} \over {{K_p}}} = {{{1 \over 2}{m_e}v_e^2} \over {{1 \over 2}{m_p}v_p^2}} = {1 \over 3}$$

($$\because$$ $${{{m_e}} \over {{m_p}}} = 3,\,{v_e} = {c \over 3}$$ and $${v_p} = c$$)

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In the circuit shown in the figure, the AC source gives a voltage V = 20 cos (2000t) neglecting source resistance, the voltmeter and ammeter reading will be
questions.explanation:
Given, R1 = 8 $$\Omega$$

R2 = 2 $$\Omega$$

L = 5 mH

C = 50 $$\mu$$F

and V0 = 20 cos (2000t)

Impedance, $$Z = \sqrt {{R^2} + {{({X_L} - {X_C})}^2}} $$

As, here, $${X_L} = \omega L = 2000 \times 5 \times {10^{ - 3}} = 10\Omega $$

Similarly, $${X_L} = {1 \over {\omega C}} = {1 \over {2000 \times 50 \times {{10}^{ - 6}}}} = 10\Omega $$

$$\because$$ $${X_L} = {X_C}$$, Hence, $${i_{\max }} = {{{V_0}} \over Z} = {{20} \over {(8 + 2)}} = 2A$$

Hence, $${i_{rms}} = {{{i_{\max }}} \over {\sqrt 2 }} = {2 \over {\sqrt 2 }} = 1.41 \,A$$

and $$V = {R_2}\,{i_{rms}} = 1.41 \times 2 = 2.82\,V$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: An electromagnetic wave is propagating along X-axis. At x = 1 cm and t = 18s, its electric vector |E| = 8 V/m, then the magnitude of its magnetic vector is
questions.explanation:
As we know that, $${E \over B} = c$$

so, $$B = {E \over c} = {8 \over {3 \times {{10}^8}}} = 2.66 \times {10^{ - 8}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A monoatomic gas of molar mass m is kept in a insulated container. Container is moving with velocity v. If the container is suddenly stopped, then the change in the temperature of the gas is
questions.explanation:
Let the insulated container has n moles of the monoatomic gas. The loss of kinetic energy of the gas,

$$\Delta {E_K} = {1 \over 2}(mn){v^2}$$

If the change in temperature of the gas is $$\Delta$$T, then heat gained by the gas is,

$$\Delta Q = {3 \over 2}nR\,\Delta T$$

Now, according to question,

$$\Delta Q = \Delta {E_K}$$

$${3 \over 2}nR\,\Delta T = {1 \over 2}mn{v^2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow \Delta T = {{m{v^2}} \over {3R}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A projectile is projected with the velocity of $$(3\widehat i + 4\widehat j)$$ m/s. The horizontal range of the projectile will be
questions.explanation:
Given, $$v = 3\widehat i + 4\widehat j$$

$$\therefore$$ $$v = |v| = \sqrt {{3^2} + {4^2}} $$

$$\Rightarrow$$ $$v = 5$$ m/s

From figure,

$$\sin \theta = {4 \over 5}$$ and $$\cos \theta = {3 \over 5}$$

$$\because$$ $$R = {{{v^2}\sin 2\theta } \over g}$$

$$ = {{{v^2}\,.\,2\sin \theta \,.\,\cos \theta } \over g}$$

$$ = {{5 \times 5 \times 2 \times {4 \over 5} \times {3 \over 5}} \over {10}} = 2.4$$ m

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A transistor is connected in common-emitter (CE) configuration. The collector supply is 8V and the voltage drop across a resistor is 500 $$\Omega$$ in the collector circuit is 0.6 V. IF the current gain factor $$\alpha$$ is 0.96, find the base current
questions.explanation:
Given, VCC = 8V

Voltage drop, V0 = $$\Delta$$IC RL = 0.6V

Load Resistor, RL = 500 $$\Omega$$

Gain factor, $$\alpha$$ = 0.96

$$\because$$ $$\beta = {\alpha \over {1 - \alpha }} = {{0.96} \over {1 - 0.96}} = 24$$

Now, V0 = $$\Delta$$IC RL

0.6 = $$\Delta$$IC $$\times$$ 500

$$\Delta$$IC = $$\frac{0.6}{500}$$ = 1.2 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$3 A

Now, $$\beta = {{\Delta {I_C}} \over {\Delta {I_B}}}$$

$$\therefore$$ Base current $$\Delta {I_B} = {{\Delta {I_C}} \over \beta } = {{1.2 \times {{10}^{ - 3}}} \over {24}} = 5 \times {10^{ - 5}}$$

= 50 $$\times$$ 10$$-$$6

$$\Delta$$IB = 50 $$\mu$$A

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A solid sphere of 80 kg and radius 15 m moving in a space becomes a circular disc of radius 20 m in 1 h. The rate of change of moment of Inertia in this process is .......
questions.explanation:
Given, mass of solid sphere = 80 kg

radius of solid sphere, Rs = 15 m

radius of circular disc, Rc = 20 m

and time = 1 hour = 60 minute = 60 $$\times$$ 60 sec

$$\therefore$$ Moment of inertia of solid sphere, Is = $$\frac{2}{5}$$ MR2

= $$\frac{2}{5}$$ $$\times$$ 80 $$\times$$ (15)2

= 7200 kg-m2

Similarly,

moment of inertia of the disc, Ic = $$\frac{1}{2}$$ MR$$_c^2$$

= $$\frac{1}{2}$$ $$\times$$ 80 $$\times$$ (20)2

= 16000 kg-m2

Rate of change of moment of Inertia $$ = {{{I_c} - {I_s}} \over t}$$

$$ = {{16000 - 7200} \over {60 \times 60}}$$

= $$\frac{22}{9}$$ kg-m2 s$$-$$1

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: If the B - H curves of two samples of X and Y of iron are as shown below, then which one of the following statement is correct?

options.content: Both X and Y are suitable for making electromagnets.
Both X and Y are suitable for making permanent magnet.
X is suitable for making permanent magnet and Y for making electromagnet.
X is suitable for making electromagnet and Y is suitable for permanent magnet.

questions.explanation: For permanent magnet we prefer a material with high retentivity and high coercivity. For electromagnet, we prefer high saturated magnetism, low coercivity and least possible area of hysteresis loop. Therefore, X is suitable for making permanent magnet and Y for making electromagnet.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In a radioactive material the activity at time t1, is A1 and at a later time t2, it is A2. If the decay constant of the material is $$\lambda$$, then
questions.explanation:
From radioactive decay law,

$$ - {{dN} \over {dt}} \propto N$$ or $$ - {{dN} \over {dt}} = \lambda N$$

Thus, $$A = - {{dN} \over {dt}}$$ or $$A = \lambda N$$

$$ \Rightarrow A = \lambda {N_0}{e^{ - \lambda t}}$$ ...... (i)

Where, $${A_0} = \lambda {N_0}$$ is the activity of the radioactive material at time, t = 0

At time, $${A_1} = {A_0}\,{e^{ - \lambda {t_1}}}$$ ..... (ii)

At time, $${A_2} = {A_0}\,{e^{ - \lambda {t_2}}}$$ ..... (iii)

On dividing Eq. (ii) by Eq. (iii), we have

$${{{A_1}} \over {{A_2}}} = {{{e^{ - \lambda {t_1}}}} \over {{e^{ - \lambda {t_2}}}}} = {e^{ - \lambda ({t_1} - {t_2})}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {A_1} = {A_2}\,{e^{ - \lambda ({t_1} - {t_2})}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A mosquito O is sitting infront of a glass rod having spherical end of radius of curvature 40 cm. The image would be formed at
questions.explanation:
As, we know, $${{{\mu _2}} \over v} - {{{\mu _1}} \over u} = {{{\mu _2} - {\mu _1}} \over R}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{1.5} \over v} - {1 \over {( - 20)}} = {{1.5 - 1} \over { + 40}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow v = - 40$$ cm

Negative sign shows that image is obtained on the same side of object i.e., towards left.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: One mole of an ideal diatomic gas undergoes a process as shown in the figure. The molar specific heat of the gas in the process is
questions.explanation:
In the curve, V $$\propto$$ $$\frac{1}{T}$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ V = m$$\frac{1}{T}$$ where, m = slope of curve.

$$\Rightarrow$$ VT = constant

$$\therefore$$ TdV + VdT = 0 ..... (i)

$$\Rightarrow$$ dV = $$-\frac{V}{T}$$dT

As, Q = $$\Delta$$U + W

CdT = CVdT + pdV ..... (ii)

CdT = CVdT $$-$$ $$\frac{p}{T}$$ VdT

$$\Rightarrow$$ C = CV $$-$$ $$\frac{pV}{T}$$

= CV $$-$$ R ($$\because$$ $$\frac{pV}{T}$$ = R)

For diatomic gas, CV = $$\frac{5}{2}$$R

$$\therefore$$ C = CV $$-$$ R = $$\frac{5}{2}$$R $$-$$ R = $$\frac{3R}{2}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A capillary tube is attached horizontally to a constant heat arrangement. If the radius of the capillary tube is increased by 25%, then the rate of flow of liquid will change nearly by
questions.explanation:
Liquid volume coming out of the tube per second

$$V = {{p\pi {r^4}} \over {8\eta l}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow V\,\alpha {r^4}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{V_2}} \over {{V_1}}} = {\left[ {{{{r_2}} \over {{r_1}}}} \right]^4} \Rightarrow {V_2} = {V_1}{\left[ {{{125} \over {100}}} \right]^4} = {V_1}{\left( {{5 \over 4}} \right)^4}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {V_2} = {V_1}(244)$$

So, now $${{\Delta V} \over V} = {{{V_2} - {V_1}} \over {{V_1}}} = {{(244){V_1} - {V_1}} \over {{V_1}}} = 144\% $$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In the arrangement shown in figure, when the switch S2 is open, the galvanometer, shows no deflection for $$l$$ = 50 cm when the switch S2 is closed, the galvanometer shows no deflection for $$l$$ = 0.416 m. The internal resistance (r) of 6 V cell is
questions.explanation:
When S2 open.

Assume resistance of XY = R.

Resistance of wire per unit length, x = $$\frac{R}{L}$$ = R $$\Omega$$ m$$-$$1

$$\because$$ I = E0 / R

Now, the potential drop across 50 cm length is 6 V, so

$$\frac{E_0}{R}$$ $$\times$$ R $$\times$$ $$\frac{50}{100}=6$$

$$\Rightarrow$$ E0 = 12 V

When S2 closed, potential drop across 0.416 cm length,

V1 = $$\frac{E_0}{R}\times$$ R $$\times\,0.416=12\times0.416\approx 5$$ V

Hence, E $$-$$ Ir = 5V

$$\Rightarrow$$ 6 $$-$$ Ir = 5

$$\because$$ I = $$\frac{5}{10}$$

$$\therefore$$ 6 $$-$$ = $$\frac{5}{10}$$r

$$\Rightarrow$$ r = 2$$\Omega$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In a young's double slit arrangement fringes are produced using light of wavelength 4000 $$\mathop A\limits^o $$. One slit is covered by a thin plate of glass of refractive index 1.4 and the other with another glass plate of same thickness but of refractive index 1.7. By doing so the central bright shifts to original sixth fringe from centre. Thickness of glass plate is ................. .
questions.explanation:
As, shift $$\Delta x = {\beta \over \lambda }(\mu - 1)t$$

Shift due to one plate $$\Delta {x_1} = {\beta \over \lambda }({\mu _1} - 1)t$$

Shift due to another path $$\Delta {x_2} = {\beta \over \lambda }({\mu _2} - 1)t$$

Net shift $$\Delta x = \Delta {x_2} - \Delta {x_1} = {\beta \over \lambda }({\mu _2} - {\mu _1})t$$ ..... (i)

Also, it is given that $$\Delta$$x = 6$$\beta$$

Hence, $$6\beta = {\beta \over \lambda }({\mu _1} - {\mu _2})t$$

$$ \Rightarrow t = {{6\lambda } \over {({\mu _1} - {\mu _2})}} = {{6 \times 4000} \over {(1.7 - 1.4)}} - 80000\,\mathop A\limits^o $$

$$ \Rightarrow t = 8 \times {10^{ - 6}} = 8\mu $$m

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: An electric current I enters and leaves a uniform circular wire of radius r through diametrically opposite points. A charged particle q moves along the axis of circular wire passes through its centre at speed v. The magnetic force on the particle when it passes through the centre has a magnitude.
questions.explanation:
Force on a moving charged particle in uniform magnetic field

$$F = Bqv\sin \theta $$ ..... (i)

Since, charge particle moves along the axis of circular current carrying loop, therefore, $$\theta$$ = 0$$^\circ$$ or 180$$^\circ$$

When $$\theta$$ = 0$$^\circ$$; $$F = Bqv\sin 0^\circ $$

F = 0

When $$\theta$$ = 180$$^\circ$$, $$F = Bqv\sin 180^\circ $$

F = 0

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: An achromatic convergent doublet of two lenses in contact has a power of +5 D. The power of converging lens is +6 D. The ratio of the dispersive power of the convergent and divergent lenses is
questions.explanation:
The condition of achromatism is $${W_1}{P_1} + {W_2}{P_2} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow {W_1}{P_1} = - {W_2}{P_2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{{W_1}} \over {{W_2}}} = - {{{P_2}} \over {{P_1}}}$$ ..... (i)

Now, $${P_1} + {P_2} = 4D$$ .... (ii)

But, power of converging lens,

$${P_1} = 5D$$

$$\because$$ Power of diverging lens,

$${P_2} = 4D - {P_1}$$ [From ii]

$$ = 4D - 5D = - D$$

$$\therefore$$ From Eq. (i) , we have

$${{{W_1}} \over {{W_2}}} = - {{{P_2}} \over {{P_1}}} = {{ - ( - D)} \over {5D}} = {1 \over 5} \Rightarrow {{{W_1}} \over {{W_2}}} = {1 \over 5}$$
